Award.AwardTitle: GSE/RES: Two Studies on Long-term Changes in the Relation Between Spatial Skills and Math Achievement in Girls

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The objective of this research is to conduct longitudinal investigations of the relationship between spatial skills and mathematics achievement in girls from families from a range of income and educational levels. One type of spatial skill, 3-d mental rotation ability, shows the largest gender differences favoring boys of any other cognitive measure, with girls using less effective strategies than boys solving these problems. For girls, in particular, this type of spatial reasoning has been found to be a strong predictor of mathematics achievement. By focusing on variability among girls from a longitudinal perspective, the purpose of the present study is to provide a nuanced account of developmental mechanisms that may promote girls' spatial and mathematics skills. The project includes two studies of the acquisition of spatial and mathematics skills in girls over time. Study 1 addresses longitudinal changes among girls in the relation between 3-d mental rotation skills and mathematics achievement from fifth through seventh grade (the period in which 3-d spatial skills are being acquired in girls). This longitudinal research will allow for more causal inferences about the links between spatial skills and mathematics achievement over this time period. Study 2 addresses the influence of girls' early skills and early mathematics experiences in the home, on their later mathematics achievement and spatial skills. This study is a follow-up of a NSF-funded study of first grade girls, in which the same sample will be assessed at fifth grade. The previous study showed that early home mathematics experiences were important predictors of mathematics achievement in first-grade girls, and mediated the association between socio-economic status and mathematics performance. This study will investigate whether these early mathematics experiences in girls have any long-term impact on their later mathematics achievement in fifth grade, when controlling for SES levels.

Broader Impacts: A careful analysis of girls' developmental changes in the relationship between spatial and mathematics skills over time will provide much needed information about the critical role that spatial ability plays in girls' STEM success and educational and occupational choices and outcomes. This may provide important educational clues on how to more effectively teach girls to develop their spatial reasoning skills and to apply them when approaching mathematics problems with the overarching goal being to broaden the participation of girls in STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Recent research has provided strong evidence for an association between spatial skills and both mathematics achievement and later success in math and science. Spatial skills involve ability to use visual imagery to solve problems, such as packing a car trunk, solving jigsaw-puzzles or putting together furniture from instructions. The present series of studies focus on girls because there is evidence of a gender difference on some types of spatial skills favoring boys, and there is very little developmental research on whether early spatial skills predict later math skills. In Study 1, the initial longitudinal study, girls' first-grade spatial skills were compared with first-grade verbal and arithmetic (addition/subtraction) skills as predictors of spatial-math reasoning (geometry/measurement) and analytical-math reasoning (number/algebra) four years later in fifth grade. First-grade spatial skills were the strongest predictors of both types of fifth-grade math reasoning. Thus, spatial skills, assessed as early as first-grade already function as key long-term predictors of analytical- as well as spatial-math reasoning skills as late as fifth grade in girls.

Using the same data, the purpose of the second longitudinal study was to was to examine what early math factors might link early spatial skills to later analytical-math reasoning. In particular, arithmetic strategy-choice in first-grade was considered as a possible pathway through which first-grade spatial skills might be predictive of later analytical-math reasoning. Earlier research with these same first-grade girls had shown that spatial skills significantly predicted greater use of two types of higher-level mental arithmetic strategies when solving arithmetic problems. These mental strategies consisted of retrieval and decomposition. Retrieval involves recalling math facts from memory, while decomposition involves breaking the problem down into simpler math facts that the child knows, and then adding or subtracting the value that remains. For example, to solve 7 + 5, one might first add 5 + 5 to get 10 and then add the remaining 2 to arrive at 12. These earlier results showed girls with higher spatial skills more likely to use mental strategies rather than counting on fingers or counters.

In Study 2, the total effect of first-grade spatial skills was significantly higher in predicting fifth-grade math reasoning than all other predictors including fifth-grade math-fact retrieval. First-grade spatial skills connected to later analytical-math reasoning through two pathways. There was both a pathway leading directly from first-grade spatial to fifth-grade math reasoning and an indirect pathway leading from spatial skills to a preference for greater use of decomposition strategy in first-grade, which in turn led to fifth-grade math reasoning. Early preference for retrieval strategies did not predict fifth-grade math reasoning. These findings suggest that early spatial skills and decomposition arithmetic strategy-use are associated, and both are predictive of later analytical-math reasoning skills.

In Study 3, the main goal was to conduct a longitudinal study in fifth, sixth, and seventh grades with a sample of 553 students in order to compare boys and girls in terms of developing relations between spatial skills and analytical-math reasoning skills during this time period. By seventh grade, the correlational pathway leading from spatial skills (fall) to analytical-math reasoning skills (spring) was higher in boys than girls. In contrast, for girls, there was a significant pathway from analytical-math reasoning (spring, sixth grade) to spatial skills (fall, seventh grade), while for boys no such significant pathway was found. These findings suggest that by seventh grade, girls were still likely to use analytical approaches for solving spatial problems, while boys were more likely than girls to apply spatial reasoning approaches to solve analytical-math reasoning problems. Consistent with the literature, boys outperformed girls on the spatial task across the three time periods.

Broader Impact

The present findings suggest that use of spatial strategies may provide an alternative set of tools in students’ problem-solving tool kits for approaching math problems when compared to those students who depend primarily on school-taught analytical strategies. Prior research has shown that spatial skills can be effectively taught. These new findings on longitudinal predictors of math reasoning in girls suggest that it may be useful to introduce spatial problem solving as well as encouraging use of alternative spatial strategies for solving math problems, right from the outset of math learning, and throughout the math learning trajectory. Both the longitudinal findings studying girls from first to fifth grade, and boys and girls from fifth to seventh grade suggest this approach may be particularly important for girls.  Schools should consider teaching and encouraging strategies, which draw on spatial visualization skills rather than focusing primarily on standard algorithms or strategies limited to logical-deductive reasoning. By introducing and teaching alternative strategies that depend on spatial reasoning across the mathematic curriculum, a wider range of students would be more likely to have access to these types of approaches to math problem solving as tools in their math problem solving toolkit.
